title:
On the completeness of several fortification-interdiction games in the
  Polynomial Hierarchy

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Fortification-interdiction games are tri-level adversarial games where two opponents act in succession to protect, disrupt and simply use an infrastructure for a specific purpose. Many such games have been formulated and tackled in the literature through specific algorithmic methods, however very few investigations exist on the completeness of such fortification problems in order to locate them rigorously in the polynomial hierarchy. We clarify the completeness status of several wellknown fortification problems, such as the Tri-level Interdiction Knapsack Problem with unit fortification and attack weights, the Max-flow Interdiction Problem and Shortest Path Interdiction Problem with Fortification, the Multi-level Critical Node Problem with unit weights, as well as a well-studied electric grid defence planning problem. For all of these problems, we prove their completeness either for the $\Sigma_{2}^{\mathrm{p}}$ or the $\Sigma_{3}^{\mathrm{p}}$ class of the polynomial hierarchy ${ }^{1}$. We also prove that the Multi-level Fortification-Interdiction Knapsack Problem with an arbitrary number of protection and interdiction rounds and unit fortification and attack weights is complete for any level of the polynomial hierarchy, therefore providing a useful basis for further attempts at proving the completeness of protection-interdiction games at any level of said hierarchy.


Keywords: Protection-interdiction games, Computational complexity, Polynomial hierarchy, Tri-level problems, electric grid protection

## 1 Introduction

The field of interdiction games has known a substantial amount of research in the last two decades. Such problems, also called Stackelberg games, represent the sequential action of two opposite players who seek to optimise the same objective function but in opposite directions. By nature such problems are bi-level, with a follower agent reacting to the decision of a leader agent. In their basic version, the follower, also named defender, tries to perform a certain action in the best possible way after the leader, or attacker, has invested a limited amount of resources to disable or disrupt some element of the problem. For example, the defender aims to maximise a flow, find a shortest path between an origin and a destination node, select a set of items given some capacity constraint, etc... whereas the attacker disables items to pack, edges or nodes of a network, etc... Such problems have become very popular, as they allow us to understand the weak points of, e.g., critical infrastructures and to assess the robustness of such infrastructures to worst-case failures or malevolent attacks. They have a wide range of possible applications, from the analysis of

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ The demonstration of the $\Sigma_{2}^{\mathrm{p}}$-completeness of the Bi-level Interdiction Knapsack Problem provided in Section 2.1 has also been accepted for publication in the proceedings of the International Conference on Optimization and Decision Science ODS2024.

electric power grids [31] or water distribution networks [39] to telecommunications [2], nuclear smuggling [34], drug network dismantling [27], public healthcare [3], and so on.

The most classical interdiction problems are based on the attack of network elements to disrupt classic graph problems, such as maximising a quantity of flow (Maximum Flow Interdiction Problem or MFIP [36]) or minimising the length of the shortest path between an origin and a destination node (Shortest Path Interdiction Problem or SPIP [20]). While these problems usually consider attacks on network arcs, other interdiction problems focus more on identifying the most vital nodes whose removal has the largest impact on network connectivity, such as the Critical Node Problem (CNP), see [23] for a survey of the literature on the CNP. Even though those problems are bi-level in nature, they are based on a lower level problem which is polynomially solvable. Hence, these problems belong to the class NP and are usually NP-complete in the general case [1, 20, 36]. More recently, harder interdiction problems have been considered, where the lower level is NP-hard and which are therefore not necessarily located in NP. This is the case of an interdiction version of the Knapsack Problem (KP), called Bi-level Interdiction Knapsack Problem (BIKP), where a leader, subject to an attack budget, can interdict a subset of items which cannot be packed by the follower when maximising the profit of the basic KP $[7,13,14,35]$. A version of this problem where the lower level KP weights are equal to the item profits is proved to be $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-complete, along with other bi-level KPs, in [8]. Other interdiction problems with an NP-hard lower level have been shown to be $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-complete, such as the Maximum Clique Interdiction Problem [18] and the Facility Location Interdiction Problem [17].

Since the interdiction games often have the aim of identifying the most vital elements of the problem at hand, a natural extension of such problems is to add another layer of decision in order to protect some of the problem elements against a possible attack. For example, an extension of the CNP (which aims at fragmenting a graph into separate maximally connected components) is proposed in [5] to add a certain number of edges in the graph prior to the nodes attack, in order to increase the robustness of the graph. The most common intervention studied to protect against interdiction is called fortification, i.e., rendering a subset of elements immune to any attack. The resulting problems have been labelled as Defender-Attacker-Defender (DAD) problems [6]. Virtually any existing interdiction problem can be extended to a fortification version of the same problem. Examples of such fortification problems, numerically tackled in the literature with several algorithmic approaches, are the Shortest Path Interdiction Problem with Fortification (SPIPF) [26, 24], the Tri-level Interdiction Knapsack Problem (TIKP) [24], the Capacitated Lot Sizing Interdiction Problem with Fortification (CLSIPF) [26] or the Travelling Salesman Problem with Interdiction and Fortification (TSPIF) [25]. Focusing more on the application side, some specific fortification problems have been investigated, such as the fortification version of an electric power grid interdiction problem, which we will call Tri-level Electric Power Grid Fortification Problem (TEPGFP) [9, 16, 38], the fortification of water distribution networks [39] or the defence of critical infrastructures in homeland security [6]. A variant of the CNP with fortification has also been considered, where the attacker can infect a subset of the graph nodes with a virus which will automatically spread through the graph edges, while a defender first vaccinates a subset of nodes against the virus and later protects a subset of nodes through quarantine after the attacker has acted. This problem is called Multi-level Critical Node Problem (MCNP) and has been introduced in [4].

Even though many works have tackled tri-level problems with fortification, surprisingly few of them address the computational complexity of such problems. Given that tri-level linear programming is in general $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-complete [21], tri-level fortification problems will in general not be in class NP, which implies that they will require advanced, sophisticated decomposition methods in order to be solved [4, 38]. In particular, no compact single level reformulation exists for such problems. Known complexity results include the $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-completeness of the TIKP with equal weights and profits for the lower level KP and the $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-completeness of the MCNP with arbitrary weights (vaccination, infection and protection weights as well as profits following the terminology introduced in the previous paragraph) over trees [28]. A few results also exist for related problems in robust programming, such as the $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$-completeness of several two-stage adjustable and robust recoverable optimisation problems with discrete budgeted uncertainty [19]. We observe that, in general, fortification problems are tackled with unitary fortification and attack costs, meaning that the fortification and interdiction budget constraints are actually cardinality constraints on the subsets of fortified and interdicted objects, probably for reasons of simplicity in designing the problem instances to tackle numerically. Hence, complexity results for such "unitary" versions are desirable.

Paper contributions: We clarify the computational complexity of several fortification problems, either directly tackled in the literature or serving as a basis for proving the completeness of other fortification problems in the future. More specifically, we prove:

- The completeness for any level of the polynomial hierarchy of the Multi-level Interdiction Knapsack Problem with an arbitrary number of fortification and interdiction rounds, with unit fortification and attack costs (therefore refining the results of $[8,28]$ ).

- The $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$-completeness of the SPIPF and TEPGFP with unit fortification costs, and of the MFIP with Fortification (MFIPF) with unit costs for both fortification and attack.
- The $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$-completeness of the MCNP with unit weights (at any level) and profits, refining the result of [28].

Paper Organisation In Section 2, we will tackle the interdiction version of the KP and show that the bi-level and tri-level versions are, respectively, $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$ and $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$-complete with unit attack and fortification costs, closing the section with a generalisation of our proof to any level of the polynomial hierarchy. In Section 3, we move to the fortification version of the MFIP and prove that it is $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-complete, still with unit attack and fortification costs. In Section 4 we prove the $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-completeness of the fortification version of the SPIP with unit fortification costs. Moving to an interdiction-fortification problem in which the attacker deletes nodes, we will demonstrate the $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$-completeness of the MCNP with only unit weights and profits in Section 5, therefore demonstrating completeness on a more general set of instances w.r.t. to the work of [28]. Finally, we will clarify the status of the TEPGFP in Appendix B by establishing its $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-complete nature and provide our conclusions.

Given the wide variety of problems tackled, where possible we keep the notation consistent with the one used in the original papers. However, we will also try and make it more uniform when necessary to avoid confusion, in particular when dealing with multi-level versions of the same problem.

# 2 The Multi-level Interdiction Knapsack Problem 

In this section we will tackle the interdiction version of the Knapsack Problem, as presented in Section 1. As already stated earlier, the computational complexity of the bi-level and tri-level versions of this problem have been investigated in the literature, for specific versions where each item has an arbitrary fortification and attack cost, plus a packing weight for the lower level (classic KP) which is equal to the item profit [8, 28]. We will consider the slightly more general version where the lower level packing weights are not equal to the profits. However, we will concentrate on versions where the fortification and attack costs are unitary. This could be useful in future endeavours on other fortification problems where such costs are also unitary, as it will allow to reduce the interdiction knapsack problems to them. Unfortunately, the reductions proposed in the previous works of $[8,28]$ are highly dependent on the presence of attack and fortification costs, which are used to differentiate between the knapsack items that are mapped to the different levels of the problems used for the reduction. It is therefore impossible to use those reductions as proposed in those works when the attack and fortification costs are unitary. We stress that our results are also interesting from a purely theoretical perspective, since in the single level KP, computational complexity tends to be strongly affected when a set of weights/profits becomes unitary (as the problem goes from being weakly NP-hard to polynomial). It is therefore a legitimate concern to establish the consequences of adopting unit costs for the higher decision levels in interdiction versions of the KP. In this section, we will establish that even with unitary fortification and attack costs, the BIKP and TIKP are respectively complete for the second and third level of the polynomial hierarchy. We will close this section by sketching how to extend the proof of completeness for any number of fortification and interdiction rounds, showing that the problem is complete for any level of the polynomial hierarchy.

### 2.1 The Bi-level Interdiction Knapsack Problem with unit attack costs

Our definition of the decision version of the Bi-level Interdiction Knapsack Problem with unit attack costs is the following. The indices used for sets and parameters refer to the decision level (1 for the defender, 2 for the attacker), for consistency with the multi-level generalisation in Section 2.3. We also adopt the convention that, when dealing with the decision version of the optimisation problems considered in this work, we drop the word Problem at the end of their name, or the $P$ at the end of their acronym.

Unitary Bilevel Interdiction Knapsack (UBIK):
INSTANCE: A finite set of items $I$ such that each $i \in I$ has a positive integer weight $w_{i}$ and a positive integer profit $p_{i}$, a positive integer capacity $W$ and a positive integer profit goal $\bar{K}$ for the follower, a positive integer budget $B_{2}$ for the leader.
QUESTION: Is there a subset $I_{2} \subseteq I$ of items for the attacker to forbid, with cardinality $\left|I_{2}\right| \leq B_{2}$, such that every subset $I_{1} \subseteq I \backslash I_{2}$ with $\sum_{i \in I_{1}} w_{i} \leq W$ that the defender can select has a total profit $\sum_{i \in I_{1}} p_{i}<\bar{K}$ ?

In order to prove that the above problem is complete for the second level of the polynomial hierarchy, we will use the following problem, known to be $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-complete [37]:

2-AlTERNATING QUANTIFIED SATISFIABILITY $\left(\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap \overline{3 C N F}\right)$ :
inSTANCE: Disjoint non-empty sets of Boolean variables $X$ and $Y$, and a Boolean expression $E$ over $U=X \cup Y$ in conjunctive normal form with at most 3 literals in each clause $c \in C$.
QUESTION: Is there a truth assignment for $X$ such that for all truth assignments of $Y, E$ is never satisfied?

We will then introduce a reduction from $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap \overline{3 C N F}$ to UBIK which draws inspiration from the reduction from 3-SAT to Subset Sum presented in [10, Theorem 34.15]. The basic idea of this reduction is to build weights, profits, capacity and profit goal of UBIK encoded in base 10, with digits associated with variables and clauses of $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap \overline{3 C N F}$, in such a way that any comparison between a sum of integer values (weights or profits) and a reference integer value (capacity or profit goal) can be performed digit by digit, without carries from lower digits to higher ones.

- For each variable $u \in U$, we create two items $i_{u}$ and $i_{\bar{u}}$, one for each possible truth assignment of $u$. We define $I_{X}=\left\{i_{x}, i_{\bar{x}}: x \in X\right\}$ and $I_{Y}=\left\{i_{y}, i_{\bar{y}}: y \in Y\right\}$. For variables $x \in X$, we introduce a third item $j_{x}$, which will serve to force the leader to choose one and only one item between $i_{x}$ and $i_{\bar{x}}$. In order to ensure a sensible mapping of the variable assignment between $Y$ and $I_{Y}$, we also introduce a fourth item $j_{x}^{\prime}$ for $x \in X$ to help saturate the budget of the follower for $X$-related digits (leaving therefore only the $Y$-related digits of the budget $W$ available for selecting items from $I_{Y}$ in $I_{1}$ ).
- For each clause $c \in C$, we create two items $i_{c}^{1}, i_{c}^{2}$. We designate by $I_{C}$ the set of items associated with $C$.
- We now introduce weights and profits for all the created items through a set of digits, each multiplied by a different power of 10 , as previously discussed. This is examplified in Table 1 where these digits are displayed in the different columns of the table and form a (large) number when put right next to each other. The least significant $|C|$ digits are labelled by the clauses, the next $|Y|$ digits by the variables $Y$, the next $2|X|$ digits by the variables $X$, two for each variable $x \in X$. Finally, the most significant positions form a set starting at position $M=|C|+|Y|+2|X|+1$. For the sake of simplicity, with a slight abuse of notation, we will sometimes refer to the integer value encoded in these positions as a "digit".
- For each $y \in Y$, the two corresponding items $i_{y}$ and $i_{\bar{y}}$ have weights and profits ( $w_{i_{y}}, p_{i_{y}}, w_{i_{\bar{y}}}$ and $p_{i_{\bar{y}}}$ ) with digit 1 in the position labelled by the variable $y$ and 0 in the positions labelled by other variables.
If literal $y$ appears in clause $c \in C$, then $p_{i_{y}}$ and $w_{i_{y}}$ have digit 1 in the position labelled as $c$, and 0 otherwise. Similarly, if literal $\neg y$ appears in clause $c \in C, p_{i_{\bar{y}}}$ and $w_{i_{\bar{y}}}$ have digit 1 in the position labelled by $c$, and 0 otherwise.
In the small example detailed in Table 1, for example, variable $c$ is the first of the two variables in $Y$ and appears in the third (and last) clause, therefore we have $w_{i_{c}}=p_{i_{c}}=10,001$.
- For each $x \in X$, the two corresponding items $i_{x}$ and $i_{\bar{x}}$ have weights $w_{i_{x}}$ and $w_{i_{\bar{x}}}$ and profits $p_{i_{x}}$ and $p_{i_{\bar{x}}}$ with digit 1 in the higher of the two positions labelled by variable $x$ and 0 in the lower one and in the positions labelled by other variables.
If literal $x$ appears in clause $c \in C$, then $p_{i_{x}}$ and $w_{i_{x}}$ have digit 1 in the position labelled as $c$, and 0 otherwise. Similarly, if literal $\neg x$ appears in clause $c \in C, p_{i_{x}}$ and $w_{i_{x}}$ have digit 1 in the position labelled by $c$, and 0 otherwise. The weights and profits have digit 0 in all remaining positions. As the first variable in $X$, present in the 1st and 3rd clause, variable $a$ from the example of Table 1 provides the weight $w_{i_{a}}=100,000,101$ and profit $p_{i_{a}}=1,100,000,101$ which differ by the leftmost digit.
The item $j_{x}$ corresponding to $x$ has weight and profit with digit 2 in the higher position labelled as $x$ (and 0 elsewhere).
The item $j_{x}^{\prime}$ corresponding to $x$ has weight $w_{j_{x}^{\prime}}$ with digit 1 in the higher position labelled as $x$ and profit $p_{j_{x}}$ with digit 1 in the lower one (and 0 elsewhere).
Using again the example of Table 1 with variable $a$, we have for item $j_{a}$ that $w_{j_{a}}=p_{j_{a}}=200,000,000$ with a digit only in the left column associated to $a$ and for item $j_{a}^{\prime}$ we have $w_{j_{a}^{\prime}}=100,000,000$ and $p_{j_{a}^{\prime}}=10,000,000$ where the profit has a digit only in the right column associated to $a$.
- For each $c \in C$, the first item has weight and profit with digit 1 in the position labelled as $c$ and 0 elsewhere, and the second item has weight and profit with digit 2 in the position labelled as $c$ and 0 elsewhere. For the first clause out of three in Table 1, we have that $w_{i_{c_{1}}^{\prime}}=p_{i_{c_{1}}}=100$ while $w_{i_{c_{2}}^{\prime}}=p_{i_{c_{2}}}=200$

![table_0](table_0)

Figure 1: Example of construction of UBIK from an instance $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap \overline{3 C N F}$ with $E=(a \vee b \vee \neg c) \wedge(\neg a \vee \neg b \vee d) \wedge$ $(a \vee b \vee c)$, where $X=\{a, b\}, Y=\{c, d\}$ and the clauses are labelled from left to right. Given the digits provided in the different columns, we have, e.g., for item $i_{a}: w_{i_{a}}=100,000,101$ and $p_{i_{a}}=1,100,000,101$.

- The attack budget $B_{2}$ is equal to $|X|$.
- The capacity $W$ has digit 1 in all positions labelled as variables in $Y, 2$ in all higher positions labelled as variables in $X, 4$ in all positions labelled as clauses in $C$, and digit 0 elsewhere. Hence, $I_{1}$ can contain any item from $I_{X}$ (as long as not interdicted).
- The profit goal $\bar{K}$ has digit 4 for all positions with labels in $C$ and 1 for all positions with labels in $U$. The positions starting at $M$ encode the integer value $|X|$.

See Figure 1 for an illustration of the proposed reduction. The reduction is polynomial because the profit goal has $|C|+|Y|+2|X|+\lceil\log _{10}|X|\rceil$ decimal digits and the other numbers are smaller.

Analysing an instance from the above reduction, we can infer the following properties:
Property 2.1. If the leader does not interdict either $i_{x}$ or $i_{\hat{x}}$ for each $x \in X$, the follower can reach the profit goal $\bar{K}$.

Proof. First of all, the attack budget forbids to interdict more than $|X|$ items. If the leader interdicts strictly less than $|X|$ items of $I_{X}$, the capacity of the follower allows to select all the uninterdicted items from $I_{X}$, reaching the profit goal $\bar{K}$. Hence, only those solutions where the leader interdicts exactly $|X|$ items from $I_{X}$ (and no item $j_{x}$ or $j_{x}^{\prime}$ for $x \in X$ ) will be of interest for the rest of the proof. For such solutions, the follower has enough capacity to select all uninterdicted items from $I_{X}$ and must select them (any other possibility leading to a failure to reach the profit goal $\bar{K}$ ). Suppose that the two items $i_{x}$ and $i_{\bar{x}}$ associated with the most significant digits whose label is $x \in X$ are taken simultaneously in $I_{2}$. In this case, the follower can select item $j_{x}$, as well as all remaining uninterdicted items of $I_{X}$, achieving a profit of $|X| 10^{M}+2 \times 10^{|C|+|Y|+2|X|}>\bar{K}$. In the example of Table 1, consider, e.g., that the leader interdicts both $i_{a}$ and $i_{\bar{a}}$ : the follower has enough capacity to select $i_{b}, i_{\bar{b}}$ and also $j_{a}$, which provides a profit of $2,200,000,000>\bar{K}$. Suppose instead that the leader selects neither $i_{x}$ nor $i_{\bar{x}}$ : since, as already stated, the follower has enough budget to select all remaining $I_{X}$ items, it is possible for $I_{1}$ to contain both $i_{x}$ and $i_{\bar{x}}$ and the profit goal $\bar{K}$ is automatically achieved, as the positions from $M$ on have value $|X|$ and the highest digit associated with $x$ is 2 . The leader must therefore interdict one item between $i_{x}$ and $i_{\bar{x}}$. Then, the follower can include item $j_{x}^{\prime}$ in $I_{1}$ in order to reach digit 1 in the lower position associated to $x$ (while not enough residual capacity is available to select item $j_{x}$ ), and must do that in order to be able to reach profit $\bar{K}$. Consequently, the capacity associated to both digits associated to $x$ is saturated.

This reasoning can then be recursively continued until we reach the lowest $X$-related position, ensuring the above property.

Property 2.2. If the leader interdicts either $i_{x}$ or $i_{\bar{x}}$ for each $x \in X$, in order to reach the profit goal $\bar{K}$ the follower must necessarily select the remaining $|X|$ uninterdicted items of $I_{X}$, all $j^{\prime}$ items and either $i_{y}$ or $i_{\bar{y}}$ for $y \in Y$.

Proof. Suppose the leader does interdict exactly one item between $i_{x}$ and $i_{\bar{x}}$ for each $x \in X$. The follower has enough capacity to select all remaining uninterdicted $I_{X}$ items and must do so, otherwise it is impossible to reach value $|X|$ at position $M$. Following the reasoning in the proof of Property 2.1, the follower must also select all $j_{x}^{\prime}$ items, in order to reach digit 1 in all the lowest digits associated to each $x \in X$, therefore saturating the capacity associated to all $X$ variables and forbidding to select any $j$ item. In order to be able to reach the profit goal, the follower must also select a subset of items from $I_{Y}$ :

- Consider the most significant digit whose label is in $Y$. Its two associated items cannot be taken simultaneously in $I_{1}$ as it would violate the weight capacity $W$. Taking none of them would forbid to achieve a profit of $\bar{K}$. Therefore, exactly one of these items must be taken, saturating the associated capacity.
- Consider the second most significant digit whose label is in $Y$. Its two associated items cannot be taken simultaneously, since that would result in a violation of the weight capacity $W$, and cannot be both neglected if the profit goal must be reached. Hence, as before, $I_{1}$ will include exactly one of the items associated with the second most significant digit in $Y$.
- The reasoning above propagates until the least significant digit labelled in $Y$.

We conclude that $I_{1}$ must include either $i_{y}$ or $i_{\bar{y}}$ for all $y \in Y$.
Theorem 2.3. UBIK is $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-complete.
Proof. The statement of UBIK is of the form $\exists I_{2} \forall I_{1} Q\left(I_{2}, I_{1}\right)$ where $Q$ can be tested in polynomial time, directly implying that it is in $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$.

As mentioned above, we use a reduction from $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap \overline{3 C N F}$ to prove the $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-hardness of UBIK.
Let $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap \overline{3 C N F}$ be a Yes instance. We form a solution to UBIK by packing in $I_{2}$ the items $i_{x}$ such that $x \in X$ is 1 and the items $i_{\bar{x}}$, otherwise. Clearly, the cardinality of $I_{2}$ is equal to $|X|$. By Property 2.2, in order to try and reach the profit goal, the follower must include in $I_{1}$ all $|X|$ items associated with $X$ not packed in $I_{2}$, all $j_{x}^{\prime}$ items for $x \in X$ and exactly one of the items $i_{y}$ or $i_{\bar{y}}$ for $y \in Y . I_{1}$ can be completed by items from $I_{C}$. However, since the $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap \overline{3 C N F}$ instance is a Yes instance, there is at least a clause for which no item from $I_{X}$ and $I_{Y}$ with a non-zero value in the associated digit can be selected. For the digit corresponding to that clause, the prize of set $I_{1}$ cannot reach value 4 using only items of $I_{C}$ and respecting the budget $W$. Therefore, UBIK is a Yes instance.

Next, suppose that UBIK is a Yes instance. According to Properties 2.1 and 2.2, $I_{2}$ must contain exactly one of the items $i_{x}$ and $i_{\bar{x}}$ for $x \in X$ and $I_{1}$ will contain exactly one item between $i_{y}$ and $i_{\bar{y}}$ for each $y \in Y$, otherwise the follower cannot achieve profit $\bar{K}$. However, since UBIK is a Yes instance, no choice of the follower allows to reach a value of 4 for all digits associated to $C$. This means that for at least one digit associated to $C$, none of the items of

$X$ and $Y$ with a digit 1 in said position can be selected. Assign value 1 to $x \in X$ such that $i_{x} \in I_{2}$, and 0 otherwise. For any set $I_{1}$ of the follower, assign 1 to $y \in Y$ if $i_{y} \in I_{1}$ and 0 if $i_{y} \in I_{1}$. Since, by hypothesis, UBIK is a Yes instance, there is no assignment of the $Y$ variables such that $E$ is satisfied in the corresponding SAT instance and the $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap \overline{3 C N F}$ instance is a Yes instance.

Although the above proof follows a basis similar to the proof of $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$-completeness of the Tri-level Interdiction Knapsack Problem in [28], it required the introduction of new features in order to deal with the symmetry between the different items from the point of view of the attacker, given the equal value of all the interdiction costs. This is the meaning of the additional $M$ column (to favour the choice of the $I_{X}$ items by the attacker) and of the $j_{x}$ and $j_{x}^{\prime}$ items (to force the attacker to interdict either $i_{x}$ or $i_{x}$ ).

# 2.2 The Tri-level Interdiction Knapsack Problem with unit attack and fortification costs 

We now demonstrate the completeness of the TIKP with unit attack and fortification costs for the third level of the polynomial hierarchy. This version of the TIKP is defined as:

## Unitary Trilevel Interdiction Knapsack (UTIK):

instance: A set of items $I$ such that each $i \in I$ has a positive integer weight $w_{i}$ and a positive integer profit $p_{i}$, a positive integer capacity $W$ and a positive integer profit goal $K$, two positive integer budgets $B_{2}$ and $B_{3}$ for attack and fortification, respectively.
QUESTION: Is there a subset $I_{3} \subseteq I$ of items, with $\left|I_{3}\right| \leq B_{3}$, such that for every subset $I_{2} \subseteq I \backslash I_{3}$, with $\left|I_{2}\right| \leq B_{2}$, there is a subset $I_{1} \subseteq I \backslash I_{2}$, with $\sum_{i \in I_{1}} w_{i} \leq W$, such that $\sum_{i \in I_{1}} p_{i} \geq K$ holds?

In order to prove the $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$-completeness of the above problem, we will use the following problem, known to be $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$ complete $[32,37]$ :

## 3-Alternating Quantified Satisfiability ( $\mathcal{B}_{3} \cap 3 C N F$ ):

instance: Disjoint non-empty sets of variables $X, Y$ and $Z$, and a Boolean expression $E$ over $U=X \cup Y \cup Z$ in conjunctive normal form with at most 3 literals in each clause $c \in C$.
QUESTION: Is there a $0-1$ assignment for $X$ such that for all $0-1$ assignments of $Y$ there is a $0-1$ assignment of $Z$ such that $E$ is satisfied?

We will then use a reduction from $\mathcal{B}_{3} \cap 3 C N F$ similar to the one used to demonstrate the $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-completeness of UBIK:

- For each variable $u \in U$, we create two items $i_{u}$ and $i_{\hat{u}}$, one for each possible $0-1$ assignment of $u$. We define $I_{X}=\left\{i_{x}, i_{\hat{x}}: x \in X\right\}, I_{Y}=\left\{i_{y}, i_{\hat{y}}: y \in Y\right\}$ and $I_{Z}=\left\{i_{z}, i_{\hat{z}}: z \in Z\right\}$. For variables of the intermediate decision level $y \in Y$, we introduce a third item $j_{y}$, which will serve to force the attacker to choose one and only one item between $i_{y}$ and $i_{\hat{y}}$, as well as a fourth item $j_{y}^{\prime}$ which will serve to force the defender to choose one and only one item between $i_{z}$ and $i_{\hat{z}}$ for each $z \in Z$.
- For each clause $c \in C$, we create two items $i_{c}^{1}, i_{c}^{2}$. We designate by $I_{C}$ the set of items associated with $C$.
- Weights, profits, maximum capacities, maximum profit and goal are positive integer numbers expressed in base 10. Each digit position is labelled by a variable or a clause, except the largest ones: the least significant $|C|$ positions are labelled by the clauses, the following $|Z|$ positions by the variables $Z$, the next $2|Y|$ positions by the variables $Y$ (two consecutive digits for each variable), then the next $|X|$ positions are labelled by the variables $X$. Finally, the most significant digits form a set starting at position $M=|C|+|Y|+2|X|+1$.
- For each $u \in X \cup Z$, the two corresponding items $i_{u}$ and $i_{\hat{u}}$ have weights and profits $w_{i_{u}}, p_{i_{u}}, w_{i_{\hat{u}}}$ and $p_{i_{u}}$ as described next. The weights and profits have digit 1 in the position labelled by the variable $u$ and 0 in the positions labelled by the other variables.

If literal $u$ appears in clause $c \in C$, then $p_{i_{u}}$ and $w_{i_{u}}$ have digit 1 in the position labelled as $c$, and 0 otherwise. Similarly, if literal $\neg u$ appears in clause $c \in C, p_{i_{u}}$ and $w_{i_{u}}$ have digit 1 in the position labelled by $c$, and 0 otherwise.

Finally, if $u \in X, p_{i_{u}}$ and $p_{i_{u}}$ have value $|Y|+1$ in the positions from $M$ on.

- For each variable $y \in Y$, the weights and profits of the two corresponding items $i_{y}$ and $i_{\bar{y}}$ have digit 1 in the higher of the two positions labelled by $y$ and 0 in the lower one and in the positions labelled by other variables.
The profits $p_{i_{y}}$ and $p_{i_{\bar{y}}}$ also have digit 1 in position $M$. If literal $y$ appears in clause $c \in C$, then $p_{i_{y}}$ and $w_{i_{y}}$ have digit 1 in the position labelled as $c$, and 0 otherwise. Similarly, if literal $\neg x$ appears in clause $c \in C, p_{i_{\bar{y}}}$ and $w_{i_{\bar{y}}}$ have digit 1 in the position labelled by $c$, and 0 otherwise.
The item $j_{y}$ corresponding to $y$ has a weight and profit with digit 2 in the highest position labelled as $y$.
Finally, the item $j_{y}^{\prime}$ has a profit with digit 1 in the lower position associated to $y$ and a weight with a digit 1 in the higher position associated to $y$, with a 0 in all remaining positions.
- For each $c \in C$, the first item has weight and profit with digit 1 in the position labelled as $c$ and 0 elsewhere, and the second item has weight and profit with digit 2 in the position labelled as $c$ and 0 elsewhere.
- The fortification budget $B_{3}$ is set equal to $|X|$ and the attack budget $B_{2}$ to $|Y|$.
- The capacity $W$ has 1 s for all digits with labels in $Z \cup X, 2$ s for all digits associated with the higher position of each label in $Y, 4$ s for all digits with labels in $C$, and 0 s elsewhere. Hence, $I_{3}$ can contain any $I_{Y}$ item (as long as not interdicted).
- The profit goal $\bar{K}$ has 1 s for all digits with labels in $U, 4$ s for all digits with labels in $C$ and the decimal encoding of $(|Y|+1)|X|+|Y|$ in the digits starting at position $M$.
See Figure 2 for an illustration of the proposed reduction on an instance with the same overall set of variables $U$ as before (distributed now over three subsets) and the same Boolean expression as in the example of Figure 1. The reduction is polynomial because the profit goal takes $|C|+|Z|+2|Y|+|X|+\left\lceil\log _{10}[(|Y|+1)|X|+|Y|]\right\rceil$ decimal digits and the other numbers are smaller.

Analysing an instance from the above reduction, we can infer the following properties:
Property 2.4. The defender can reach the profit goal $\bar{K}$ only fortifying either $i_{x}$ or $i_{\bar{x}}$ for each $x \in X$.
Proof. First of all, if the defender wants to reach the profit goal, it is mandatory to fortify $|X|$ items in $I_{X}$. Otherwise, the attacker can interdict both $i_{x}$ and $i_{\bar{x}}$ for a given $x \in X$, as long as $|Y|>1$, and forbid the defender from reaching value $(|Y|+1)|X|$ in the digits from $M$ on, and thus the profit goal.
Consider the most significant digit whose label is in $X$. If the defender fortifies neither $i_{x}$ nor $i_{\bar{x}}$, as stated above, the attacker can prevent the achievement of the profit goal $\bar{K}$. However, if both $i_{x}$ and $i_{\bar{x}}$ are fortified, given the fortification budget, there is a variable $x^{\prime} \in X$ with $x^{\prime} \neq x$ for which neither $i_{x^{\prime}}$ nor $i_{\bar{x}^{\prime}}$ can be fortified: consider the one with the most significant digit position. Consequently, as explained above, the attacker will interdict both such items and the defender, being unable to select more than one $I_{X}$ item for each position higher than $x^{\prime}$, will not reach $\bar{K}$. The reasoning can be propagated by induction to each variable of $X$.

Property 2.5. If the defender fortifies either $i_{x}$ or $i_{\bar{x}}$ for each $x \in X$, any solution $I_{2}$ for the attacker which does not select either $i_{y}$ or $i_{\bar{y}}$ for $y \in Y$ allows the defender to automatically reach the profit goal $\bar{K}$.

Proof. As stated in the proof of Property 2.4, once exactly one item between $i_{x}$ and $i_{\bar{x}}$ is fortified by the defender, the attacker has no incentive to attack the remaining unfortified items from $I_{X}$ as: i) the defender cannot select more than the fortified items from $I_{X}$ at the lowest decision level due to the structure of $W$; ii) since all $|X|$ fortified items are selected at the lowest level, if the attacker does not forbid exactly $|Y|$ items from $I_{Y}$, the defender can select all uninterdicted $I_{Y}$ items and achieve automatically the profit $\bar{K}$. For an attacker's solution which does not interdict any item from $I_{X}$, the conditions for Property 2.1 apply, which completes the proof.

Property 2.6. If the defender fortifies either $i_{x}$ or $i_{\bar{x}}$ for each $x \in X$ and the attacker interdicts either $i_{y}$ or $i_{\bar{y}}$ for each $y \in Y$, in order to reach the profit goal $\bar{K}$ the follower must necessarily select in $I_{1}$ the $|X|$ fortified items of $I_{X}$, the remaining $|Y|$ uninterdicted items of $I_{Y}$, all $j_{y}^{\prime}$ items and either $i_{z}$ or $i_{z}$ for $z \in Z$.

Proof. In order to reach the profit goal $\bar{K}$, the defender must select $|X|$ items from $I_{X}$. Moreover, due to the structure of $W$, the choice must consist of one item between $i_{x}$ and $i_{\bar{x}}$ for each $x \in X$. Indeed, one can see that for the highest $X$-related position, the defender must select only one item due to the budget limit. After having selected this item, the

![table_1](table_1)

Figure 2: Example of construction of UTIK from an instance $\mathcal{B}_{3} \cap 3 C N F$ with $E=(a \vee b \vee \neg c) \wedge(\neg a \vee \neg b \vee d) \wedge$ $(a \vee c \vee b)$, where $X=\{a\}, Y=\{b\}, Z=\{c, d\}$ and the clauses are labelled from left to right.
budget for this specific column has no residual capacity and the reasoning can be applied iteratively down to the lowest $X$-related digit. At which point, we are in a situation where Property 2.2 can be invoked, completing the proof.

Theorem 2.7. UTIK is $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$-complete.
Proof. The statement of UTIK is of the form $\exists I_{3} \quad \forall I_{2} \exists I_{1} \quad Q\left(I_{1}, I_{2}, I_{3}\right)$ where $Q$ can be tested in polynomial time, directly implying that it is in $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$.
Let $\mathcal{B}_{3} \cap 3 C N F$ be a Yes instance. We form a solution to UTIK by packing in $I_{1}$ the items $i_{x}$ such that $x \in X$ is 1 and the items $i_{\bar{x}}$, otherwise. Clearly, the cardinality of $I_{1}$ is equal to $|X|$. We can then apply Property 2.5 to justify that either UTIK is automatically a Yes instance or the attacker interdicts exactly one item between $i_{y}$ and $i_{\bar{y}}$ for each $y \in Y$. At which point, the defender selects exactly one item between $i_{z}$ and $i_{\bar{z}}$ in $I_{1}$ for each $z \in Z$ by virtue of Property 2.6, otherwise the instance is automatically a No instance. Finally, $I_{1}$ is completed by items from $I_{C}$. We can easily map any choice of set $I_{2}$ to a choice of variables $Y$ in the SAT problem by setting a variable $y \in Y$ at 1 if item $i_{y}$ is chosen and 0 if instead item $i_{y}$ is chosen. For a given set $I_{2}$, we can also map any set $I_{1}$ to a valid choice of variables from $Z$ in the SAT problem. Since the $\mathcal{B}_{3} \cap 3 C N F$ instance is a Yes instance, it follows that the corresponding UTIK

instance is also a Yes instance, as it is possible, for any position $c \in C$, to select an item from $I_{U}$ which will provide a non-zero contribution in column $c$, which can then be exactly upgraded to value 4 by selecting items from $I_{C}$.

Next, suppose that UTIK is a Yes instance. From Property 2.4 we know that $I_{3}$ must contain exactly one of the items $i_{x}$ and $i_{\bar{x}}$ for each $x \in X$. It follows, by virtue of Property 2.5 , that the non-trivial interdiction solution $I_{2}$ contains exactly one item between $i_{y}$ and $i_{\bar{y}}$ for each $y \in Y$. Finally, by invoking Property 2.6 , we know that solution $I_{1}$ contains exactly one item between $i_{z}$ and $i_{\bar{z}}$ for each $z \in Z$. There is, therefore, a straightforward mapping between any non trivial $I_{2}$ and $Y$ on the one hand and $I_{1}$ and $Z$ on the other. Following a similar reasoning as in the UBIK proof, we conclude that the $\mathcal{B}_{3} \cap 3 C N F$ is a Yes instance.

# 2.3 Extension to any level of the polynomial hierarchy 

It is possible to extend the Knapsack Interdiction game to an arbitrary number of levels. Suppose that, additionally to the lowest level, which is a regular KP, we allow for $m$ levels above it which alternate between rounds of interdiction and fortification. The full problem is, therefore, an $(m+1)$-level optimisation problem, where the case with $m=1$ is the BIKP and the case with $m=2$ is the TIKP. If $m$ is odd, the highest level is an interdiction round, while if $m$ is even it is a fortification round. As in the previous subsections, we suppose that all fortification and interdiction costs are unitary. Moreover, an item which is fortified or interdicted in a certain decision round remains so in the subsequent ones and a fortified item cannot be interdicted. We formally define the following problems:

```
Unitary Multi-Level Interdiction Knapsack (UMIK):
instance: A set of items \(I\) such that each \(i \in I\) has a positive integer weight \(w_{i}\) and
a positive integer profit \(p_{i}\), a positive integer capacity \(W\) and a positive integer profit
goal \(\bar{K}\), as well as \(m\) positive integer budgets \(B_{2}, \ldots, B_{m+1}\) for attack and fortification,
respectively.
QUeStion: \(\exists I_{m+1} \forall I_{m} \ldots \forall I_{1}\) (for \(m\) even) or \(\exists I_{m+1} \forall I_{m} \ldots \exists I_{1}\) (for \(m\) odd) with \(\left|I_{l}\right| \leq B_{l}\)
for \(l \geq 2, \sum_{i \in I_{l}} w_{i} \leq W, I_{m} \subseteq I \backslash I_{m+1}, I_{m-1} \subseteq I \backslash I_{m}, \ldots, I_{1} \subseteq I \backslash \cup_{l=1}^{\left\lfloor\frac{m+1}{2}\right\rfloor} I_{2 l}\) such
that \(\sum_{i \in I_{l}} p_{i} \geq \bar{K}\) (if \(m\) is even) or \(\sum_{i \in I_{l}} p_{i}<\bar{K}\) (if \(m\) is odd) holds?
```

In order to prove the $\Sigma_{m+1}^{p}$-completeness of the above problem, we will use the following problems, known to be $\Sigma_{m+1}^{p}$-complete $[32,37]$ :

```
\(m+1\)-Alternating Quantified Satisfiability \(\left(\mathcal{B}_{m+1} \cap \overline{3 C N F}\right.\) with \(m\) odd,
or \(\mathcal{B}_{m+1} \cap 3 C N F\) with \(m\) even \()\)
INSTANCE: Disjoint non-empty sets of variables \(X_{l}\) for \(l=1, \ldots, m+1\), and a Boolean
expression \(E\) over \(\cup_{l=1}^{m+1} X_{l}\) in conjunctive normal form with at most 3 literals in each
clause \(c \in C\).
QUeStion: \(\exists X_{m+1} \forall X_{m} \ldots \forall X_{1}: \quad E\) is never satisfied? (for \(m\) odd) or
\(\exists X_{m+1} \forall X_{m} \ldots \exists X_{1}: E\) is satisfied? (for \(m\) even)
```

We state the following:
Theorem 2.8. UMIK with $m$ alternate rounds of fortification and interdiction and with unit fortification and attack costs is $\Sigma_{m+1}^{p}$-complete.
Since it uses mainly ingredients introduced in the previous proofs, the proof is relegated to Appendix A.
We can make an interesting general remark regarding the UMIKP for any number of fortification and interdiction rounds:

Property 2.9. When either the profits or the weights of the lowest-level KP become unitary, UMIKP becomes solvable in polynomial time.
This is straightforward since any round of fortification or attack will concentrate on those items not already fortified or interdicted with either higher profit (for unit weights) or higher weights (for unit profits) so the choices at each level are straightforward. We conclude that there is therefore no intermediate situation in this regard, the problems are either complete for their natural complexity class in the polynomial hierarchy, or they become polynomial. This, of course, does not take into account the possibility of having specially structured weight or profit sets which are not simply all unitary.

# 3 The Max-Flow Interdiction Problem with Fortification 

Given that the MFIP is the prototype of an NP-complete interdiction problem [36] and many works exist on network interdiction which are based on some kind of network flow [11, 15, 22, 33], we propose to study a fortification version of this problem which can serve as a basis for studying the complexity of flow-based fortification-interdiction problems. We therefore start this section by defining a straightforward extension of the MFIP to a fortification tri-level version and proceed to demonstrate that this problem is complete for the second level of the polynomial hierarchy, even considering unit fortification and attack costs.

The Max-Flow Interdiction Problem with Fortification The MFIPF is defined over a directed graph $G=(V, A)$, where each arc $(i, j) \in A$ is associated with a maximum capacity $c_{i j}$, an attack cost $w_{i j}$ and a fortification cost $b_{i j}$. The aim of the defender is to maximise the amount of flow through the graph, from a source node $s$ to a destination node $t$. The attacker selects a subset of arcs $D$ to destroy, given an attack budget $W$ (that is, $\sum_{(i, j) \in D} w_{i j} \leq W$ ), in order to minimise the maximum flow from $s$ to $t$ on the graph induced by the arc removal. Before the attack, the defender can take preventive actions that consist, given a fortification budget $B$, in selecting a subset of arcs $F$ which become immune to any attack (that is, $\sum_{(i, j) \in F} b_{i j} \leq B$ ). The unitary version of the problem considers only unit attack and fortification costs.
$\Sigma_{g}^{p}$-completeness of the MFIPF with unit costs We now proceed to demonstrate the completeness of the MFIPF with unit costs in the second level of the polynomial hierarchy.

```
Unitary Max-Flow Interdiction Problem with Fortification (UM-
FIPF):
```

INSTANCE: A directed graph $G=(V, A)$ with a maximum integer capacity $c_{i j}$ for each $(i, j) \in A$, a source and a destination node $s, t \in V$, a positive integer flow goal $\bar{K}$ and two positive integer budgets $W$ and $B$ for attack and fortification.
QUESTION: Is there a subset $F \subseteq A$ of arcs, with $|F| \leq B$, such that for every subset $D \subseteq A \backslash F$, with $|D| \leq W$, the value of the maximum flow from $s$ to $t$ in the induced graph $G_{D}=(V, A \backslash D)$ is at least $\bar{K}$ ?

In order to prove the $\Sigma_{g}^{p}$-completeness of the above problem, we will use $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap 3 C N F$, known to be $\Sigma_{g}^{p}$-complete [21]:

#### Abstract

2-AlTERNATING QUANTIFIED SATISFIABILITY $\left(\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap 3 C N F\right)$ : INSTANCE: Disjoint non-empty sets of variables $X$ and $Y$, and a Boolean expression $E$ over $U=X \cup Y$ in conjunctive normal form with at most 3 literals in each clause $c \in C$. QUESTION: Is there a $0-1$ assignment for $X$ so that for all $0-1$ assignments of $Y, E$ is always satisfied?


The reduction from $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap 3 C N F$ is obtained by the following process, that builds a four-level directed graph $G=$ $(V, A)$, in which the first and the last level consist, respectively, of a source node $s$ and a destination node $t$, while the rest of the graph connects $s$ to $t$ through suitable gadgets, associated with the different components of the SAT instance (variables in $X$ and $Y$, and clauses). The capacity of the arcs in these gadgets are tuned so as to impose fortification and attack strategies corresponding to consistent truth assignments in the SAT instance.

- For each variable $x \in X$, we design the gadget illustrated on the left side of Figure 3. First, we introduce two nodes $v_{x}$ and $v_{\bar{x}}$, and two $\operatorname{arcs}\left(s, v_{x}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{\bar{x}}\right)$. Then, we add $M=3|Y|$ nodes, $u_{x}^{1}$ to $u_{x}^{M}$, one arc from $v_{x}$ to each $u_{x}^{i}$ with $i=1, \ldots, 2|Y|$ and one arc from $v_{\bar{x}}$ to each $u_{x}^{i}$ with $i=|Y|+1, \ldots, 3|Y|$. Finally, we add one arc from each $u_{x}^{i}$ with $i=1, \ldots, M$ to $t$. We set the capacity of $\operatorname{arcs}\left(s, v_{x}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{\bar{x}}\right)$ to $c_{x v_{x}}=c_{X}+\gamma_{x}$ and $c_{x v_{\bar{x}}}=c_{X}+\gamma_{\bar{x}}$, where $\gamma_{x}$ and $\gamma_{\bar{x}}$ are, respectively, the number of clauses of expression $E$ in which $x$ and $\bar{x}$ appear, whereas $c_{X}$ is a suitable large number defined and motivated in the following. The other arcs of the gadget have capacity $c_{u}=\frac{c_{x}}{2|Y|}$. By construction, the arc cut between node $v_{x}$ and all nodes $u_{x}^{i}$ has a total capacity of $c_{X}$, same as the cut between $v_{\bar{x}}$ and nodes $u_{x}^{i}$, while the arc cut between all nodes $u_{x}^{i}$ and $t$ has a total capacity of $\frac{3 c_{X}}{2}$. The aim of this gadget is to ensure that the defender will fortify only one arc between $\left(s, v_{x}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{\bar{x}}\right)$.
- For the variable subset $Y$, we introduce another gadget, a small significant part of which is reported on the right side of Figure 3: for each literal $(\lambda=y$ or $\lambda=\bar{y})$, we add a node $v_{\lambda}$ and an $\operatorname{arc}\left(s, v_{\lambda}\right)$. Then, for

each unordered pair of literals $\left\{\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right\}$ with $\lambda \neq \lambda^{\prime}$, we introduce a node $u_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}$ along with arcs $\left(v_{\lambda}, u_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}\right)$ and $\left(v_{\lambda^{\prime}}, u_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}\right)$. Finally, we add an arc $\left(u_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}, t\right)$. The capacity of $\left(s, v_{\lambda}\right)$ is $c_{s v_{\lambda}}=c_{Y}+\gamma_{\lambda}$, where $\gamma_{\lambda}$ is defined similarly as for the $X$-related gadgets and $c_{Y}$ is set to a suitable large number defined and motivated in the following. The arcs $\left(v_{\lambda}, u_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}\right)$ have capacity $c_{Y}^{\prime}$, defined and motivated in the following. The arcs $\left(u_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}, t\right)$ have capacity $c_{Y}^{\prime}$ if $\lambda^{\prime}=\lambda$ and $2 c_{Y}^{\prime}$ otherwise. The aim of this gadget is to force the attacker to interdict only one arc between $\left(s, v_{y}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{\bar{y}}\right)$ for any $y \in Y$.

- For each clause $c \in C$, we introduce the following simple gadget: we add to $V$ a single node $v_{c}$, with one outgoing arc to $t$ and an incoming arc from each of the nodes $v_{u}$ or $v_{a}$ for $u \in U$ that corresponds to a literal occurring in clause $c$. All these arcs have capacity 1 . Hence, in order to have a unitary flow from $v_{c}$ to $t$, we need to have at least an ingoing unit of flow from the node corresponding to exactly one of the literals involved in $c$.
- We set the values for the following constants: the fortification budget is $B=|X|$, the attack budget $W=$ $|X|+|Y|$, and the flow goal $K=|X| c_{X}+2|Y|(|Y|-1) c_{Y}^{\prime}+|C|$. Finally, $c_{Y}^{\prime}=|C|+1, c_{Y}=(2|Y|-1) c_{Y}^{\prime}$, $c_{X}=(2|Y|-1) c_{Y}$. These values guarantee that attacking an arc $\left(s, v_{\lambda}\right)$ for $\lambda$ an $X$-related literal reduces the maximum flow by at least $c_{X} / 2$, making such an attack more profitable than $|Y|-1$ attacks on arcs from $Y$ or $C$-related gadgets in the graph. This makes such arcs the most profitable to fortify or attack for both defender and attacker. The values of $c_{Y}$ and $c_{Y}^{\prime}$ also make it much more profitable for the attacker to disable an arc $\left(s, v_{\lambda}\right)$ with $\lambda$ a $Y$-related literal, instead of an $\operatorname{arc}\left(v_{\lambda}, u_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}\right)$ or $\left(u_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}, t\right)$ with capacity $c_{Y}^{\prime}$, or an arc of the $C$-related gadgets.

The structure of the graph is such that the flow from $s$ to $t$ is the sum of the flow through the $X$-related gadgets, the $Y$-related gadget and the $C$-related gadgets. Moreover, the capacities are tuned so as to guarantee that the three contributions to the total flow have different orders of magnitude, so that the second and the third one cannot compensate a nonoptimal value for the first. The reduction is obviously polynomial and does not involve any number which is exponentially large in the instance size.
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 3: Example of the gadget associated with a variable $x \in X$ (on the left side) and the part of the gadget associated with subset $Y$ related to $y, \bar{y}$ and $y, y^{\prime}$ (on the right side).

The introduced gadgets imply the following properties:
Property 3.1. If the defender does not fortify exactly one arc between $\left(s, v_{x}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{\bar{x}}\right)$ for each $x \in X$, the attacker can forbid the defender to reach the flow goal $K$.

Proof. If the defender fortifies strictly less than $|X| \operatorname{arcs}\left(s, v_{x}\right)$ or $\left(s, v_{\bar{x}}\right)$ in the $X$-related gadgets, the attacker can forbid to reach the flow goal. In fact, by interdicting at least $|X|+1$ of such arcs, a maximum of $(|X|-1) c_{X}$ units of flow can pass through the $X$-related gadgets. Moreover, the part of the graph containing the $Y$ and $C$-related gadgets allows for a maximum flow of $2|Y| c_{Y}+|C|$ units of flow. With $|Y|>1$ and additional interdictions by the attacker, the total flow travelling through the rest of the graph will not be sufficient to compensate for the loss of $c_{X}$ units of flow through the $X$-related gadgets. Therefore, the defender must spend the whole fortification budget $B=|X|$ on those arcs. If the defender does not fortify exactly one such ingoing arc for each $X$-related gadget, it means that in some of these gadgets, none or both ingoing arcs are fortified, because $B=|X|$. By fortifying both ingoing arcs, the defender can only hope to save an additional $c_{X} / 2$ units of flow for this gadget, with respect to the case where only arc is fortified, given the total capacity of $\frac{3 c_{X}}{2}$ of the rightmost arcs of the gadgets. Moreover, it leaves another

gadget completely unfortified and given that the attacker's budget is larger than $|X|$, that gadget will be completely interdicted. Hence, the defender must fortify exactly one arc in each $X$-related gadget, guaranteeing a minimum flow of $|X| c_{X}$ through such gadgets, otherwise the flow goal cannot be reached.

Property 3.2. Supposing that the defender has fortified exactly one arc between $\left(s, v_{x}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{x}\right)$ for each $x \in X$, if the attacker does not disable the corresponding unfortified arcs and exactly one arc between $\left(s, v_{y}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{\bar{y}}\right)$ for each $y \in Y$, the defender automatically reaches the flow goal $\bar{K}$.

Proof. For each variable $x \in X$, the total flow going through the related gadget can reach a maximum of $3 c_{X} / 2$ and disabling the remaining unfortified arc between $\left(s, v_{x}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{\bar{x}}\right)$ alone decreases the total flow by $c_{X} / 2$. This is more effective than disabling any other arc in the graph. Therefore, the attacker will first spend $|X|$ units to disable those arcs. If the attacker interdicts other arcs of the X-related gadgets, the flow can only be reduced by $c_{u}=\frac{(2|Y|-1) c_{Y}}{2|Y|} \leq c_{Y}$, which is less effective than attacking an arc $\left(s, v_{y}\right)$ or $\left(s, v_{\bar{y}}\right)$. With the given capacities, disabling these arcs is also more effective than disabling other arcs of the $Y$-related gadget. Now, the maximum flow that can traverse the $Y$-related gadgets, if no arc is interdicted, is $\|Y|+4|Y|(|Y|-1)| c_{Y}^{\prime}$. Interdicting an arc $\left(s, v_{\lambda}\right)$ with $\lambda \in\{y, \bar{y}\}$ reduces this flow by $c_{Y}^{\prime}$ units for each arc $\left(v_{\lambda}, u_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}\right)$, except when $\lambda^{\prime}=\bar{\lambda}$. In that case, in fact, $c_{Y}^{\prime}$ units of flow are forbidden only if both $\left(s, v_{\lambda}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{\bar{\lambda}}\right)$ are disabled. Therefore, if the attacker interdicts these two arcs, swapping the interdiction of one such arc with an uninterdicted arc $\left(s, v_{\lambda^{\prime \prime}}\right)$ such that $\lambda^{\prime \prime} \neq \lambda$ and $\lambda^{\prime \prime} \neq \bar{\lambda}$ allows to decrease the total flow from $s$ to $t$ by $c_{Y}^{\prime}$ units. Given that, when the attacker disables exactly one ingoing arc between $\left(s, v_{y}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{\bar{y}}\right)$ for each $y \in Y$, the total flow through the $Y$ gadget is equal to $2|Y|(|Y|-1) c_{Y}^{\prime}$. Any other choice will amount to a quantity of flow that will automatically reach $\bar{K}$.

Theorem 3.3. UMFIPF is $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-complete.
Proof. The statement of UMFIPF is of the form $\exists F \forall D Q(F, D)$ where $Q$ can be tested in polyomial time since the Max-Flow Problem is in P, directly implying that it is in $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$.

Let $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap 3 C N F$ be a Yes instance. We form a solution to UMFIPF by protecting the following arcs. For each variable $x \in X$, if $x=1$, we fortify arc $\left(s, v_{x}\right)$ by adding it in $F$; otherwise, we fortify $\operatorname{arc}\left(s, v_{x}\right)$. This obviously respects the fortification budget $B=|X|$ and allows a flow of $|X| c_{X}$ units through the $X$-related gadgets. According to Property 3.2, each attacker's solution that will not attack exactly one arc between $\left(s, v_{y}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{\bar{y}}\right)$ for each $y \in Y$ ensures that the defender will reach the flow goal. It is therefore possible to generate a mapping with the second level of the $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap 3 C N F$ instance as follows: for each arc $\left(s, v_{y}\right)$ selected in $D$, assign value 0 to variable $y$; if $\left(s, v_{\bar{y}}\right)$ is selected in $D$, assign value 1 to variable $y$. Notice that the mapping between both problems is inverted with respect to the mapping for $X$ variables: this is due to the fact that interdicting, say, arc $\left(s, v_{y}\right)$ in UMFIPF implies that no unit of flow from that arc reach any clause node $v_{c}$ for $c \in C$ which contains $y$, corresponding to a situation where the $y$ variable is false in $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap 3 C N F$. Since the $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap 3 C N F$ is a Yes instance, any assignment of $Y$ variables guarantees that each clause has at least one literal at value 1 . Hence, for each clause $c \in C$, there is an ingoing arc for $v_{c}$ corresponding to a literal $\lambda=u$ or $\bar{u}$ for some $u \in U$ which is true in $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap 3 C N F$. Given the way we have built our reduction, a non-zero flow can circulate through this arc. Given the capacity of the $\operatorname{arc}\left(s, v_{\lambda}\right)$, we can make a unit of flow circulate on $\operatorname{arc}\left(v_{\lambda}, v_{c}\right)$ and then on $\operatorname{arc}\left(v_{c}, t\right)$. We can therefore add one unit of flow per clause, that is $|C|$ overall, and reach the flow goal $\bar{K}$, and our UMFIPF instance is a Yes instance.

Conversely, let UMFIPF be a Yes instance. According to Property 3.1, the fortification budget of the defender needs to be spent on arcs $\left(s, v_{x}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{\bar{x}}\right)$ for $x \in X$ and exactly one such arc needs to be fortified for each $x \in X$. Using Property 3.2, the best strategy for the attacker is to interdict exactly one arc between $\left(s, v_{y}\right)$ and $\left(s, v_{\bar{y}}\right)$ for each variable $y \in Y$. We can therefore adopt a mapping such that for each $x \in X, x=1$ if $\left(s, v_{x}\right)$ is fortified and 0 otherwise, and for each $y \in Y, y=0$ if $\left(s, v_{y}\right)$ is interdicted and 1 otherwise. Since the UMFIPF is a Yes instance, and the flow going through all of the $X$ and $Y$ gadgets going directly to node $t$ is equal to $|X| c_{X}+2|Y|(|Y|-1) c_{Y}^{\prime}$, it means that one unit of flow has to go through each of the clause gadgets. Since this flow comes from the $v_{u}$ or $v_{\bar{u}}$ nodes, it means that for each clause $c \in C$, a corresponding literal is equal to one and the $\mathcal{B}_{2} \cap 3 C N F$ is a Yes instance.

# 4 The Shortest Path Interdiction Problem with Fortification 

The SPIP is a classic network interdiction problem which has been tackled under many different forms, ranging from the most basic one [20] to more refined versions with uncertain and asymmetric information [29]. It is formulated on a directed graph with a given source node and destination node, and consists in an attacker selecting a subset of arcs subject to a certain attack budget, in order to maximise the length of the shortest path that a defender can find from the

source to the destination. The fortification version of this problem, where the defender can take preventive actions by fortifying a subset of arcs subject to a fortification budget, is considered as a basic problem in fortification-interdiction games and has been used as an example problem for applying generic tri-level fortification algorithmic frameworks in several works [24, 26]. The version advocated in such works is usually one with unit fortification and attack costs. In this section, we will first present the general SPIP with Fortification (SPIPF), then we will prove the $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-completeness of a version of SPIPF with unit fortification costs.

Problem definition The SPIPF is defined over a directed graph $G=(V, A)$, where each arc $(i, j) \in A$ is associated with a length $d_{i j}$, an attack cost $w_{i j}$ and a fortification cost $b_{i j}$. The aim of the defender is to find a path of minimum length between a source node $s$ and a destination node $t$. The attacker seeks to interdict a set of arcs $D$, given a maximum attack budget $W^{\prime}$ (i.e., $\sum_{(i, j) \in D} w_{i j} \leq W^{\prime}$ ), in order to maximise the length of the shortest path on the graph induced by the arc removal. Before the attacker operates, the defender can take preventive actions to fortify a subset of arcs $F$, which become immune to any attack, given a maximum fortification budget $B^{\prime}$ (i.e., $\sum_{(i, j) \in F} b_{i j} \leq$ $B^{\prime}$ ). The unitary version of that problem considers only unit fortification costs, but arbitrary attack costs.

# Shortest Path Interdiction Problem with Unitary Fortification (SPIPUF): 

INSTANCE: A directed graph $G=(V, A)$ with an integer length $d_{i j}$ and an attack cost $w_{i j}$ for each $(i, j) \in A$, a source and destination node $s, t \in V$, two positive integer budgets $W^{\prime}$ and $B^{\prime}$ and a positive integer goal $\bar{K}^{\prime}$.
QUESTION: Is there a subset $F \subseteq A$ of arcs, with $|F| \leq B^{\prime}$, such that for every subset $D \subseteq A \backslash F$, with $\sum_{(i, j) \in D} w_{i j} \leq W^{\prime}$, the length of the shortest path from $s$ to $t$ in the induced graph $G_{D}=(V, A \backslash D)$ is strictly less than $\bar{K}^{\prime}$ ?
$\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-completeness of SPIPF with unit fortification costs We now proceed to demonstrate the $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-completeness of the SPIPF with unit fortification costs. To this purpose, we will use UBIK, demonstrated to be in the second level of the polynomial hierarchy in Section 2.
Theorem 4.1. SPIPUF is $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$-complete.
Proof. The statement of SPIPUF is of the form $\exists F \forall D Q(F, D)$, where $Q$ can be tested in polynomial time, since the Shortest Path Problem is in P, directly implying that SPIPUF is in $\Sigma_{2}^{p}$.
Let us introduce the following reduction from UBIK:

- We label each of the items in UBIK with a number from 1 to $n=|I|$.
- We introduce in set $V$ a node $v_{k}$ for each item $k \in\{1, \ldots, n\}$ and a source node $v_{0}$; node $v_{n}$ will serve as destination node.
- For each item $i \in I=\{1, \ldots, n\}$, we introduce the following gadget: add an $\operatorname{arc}\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}\right)$ with length $p_{i}+2$ and attack cost $W+1$, a node $v_{i}^{\prime}$ and $\operatorname{arcs}\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ with length 1 and attack cost $w_{i}$ and $\left(v_{i}^{\prime}, v_{i}\right)$ with length 1 and attack cost $W+1$.
- We set the fortification budget $B^{\prime}$ to $B_{2}$, i.e. the value of the attack budget in UBIK, the attack budget $W^{\prime}$ to $W$, i.e. the value of the weight capacity of UBIK, and the goal for the shortest path length to $\bar{K}^{\prime}=\bar{K}+2 n$. By construction, therefore, only the $\operatorname{arcs}\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ can be attacked, and only within the capacity of the knapsack.

We provide a graphical view of the reduction in Figure 4. Notice that the defender and the attacker adopt a reverse perspective in the two problems: fortifying arcs in SPIPUF corresponds to interdicting items in UBIK, and attacking arcs in SPIPUF to selecting items in UBIK. In fact, the rationale is to solve the KP by minimising the total profit of the items not selected.

Let UBIK be a Yes instance. We form a solution to SPIPUF as follows: if item $i \in I$ is interdicted by the attacker in UBIK, we fortify the arc $\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}^{\prime}\right)$, after which no more fortification budget remains. Now the attacker in SPIPUF can attack only the unfortified $\operatorname{arcs}\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ with $i=1, \ldots, n$. For each set of attacked arcs $D$, the shortest path from $v_{0}$ to $v_{n}$ is easily determined: for each $i=1, \ldots, n$, if $\operatorname{arc}\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ is attacked, the defender has to use $\operatorname{arc}\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}\right)$ with length $p_{i}+2$; otherwise, the defender will use $\operatorname{arcs}\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ and $\left(v_{i}^{\prime}, v_{i}\right)$ with total length 2 . The worst case occurs when the attacker selects the attacked $\operatorname{arcs}\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ so that the sum of the profits $p_{i}$ on the alternative arcs $\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}\right)$ is maximum. Since for each $i=1, \ldots, n$ we either travel a length 2 or $p_{i}+2$ (if an arc is interdicted in the associated gadget), the interdiction of an $\operatorname{arc}\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ in SPIPUF corresponds to the selection of an item in UBIK. Since UBIK is a Yes instance, we cannot achieve a profit of $\bar{K}$ or more; hence, the shortest path length cannot reach $\bar{K}+2 n$. Therefore, the SPIPUF is a Yes instance.

![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Figure 4: Example of the graph obtained after reducing to SPIPUF. The label for each arc provides the length and the attack cost of the arc.

Conversely, assume that the SPIPUF is a Yes instance. Only the $\operatorname{arcs}\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$ are worth fortifying, since the other ones cannot be interdicted respecting the budget. Given a solution to SPIPUF, we can right away map the fortified arcs onto the corresponding items of UBIK. Since SPIPUF is a Yes instance, the attacker cannot interdict a set of $\left(v_{i-1}, v_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ arcs that at the same time has a total attack budget not larger than $W$ and increases the shortest path length by at least $\bar{K}$. Mapping any set of interdicted arcs to the corresponding items in UBIK, we have that no item selection in UBIK can reach the profit goal $\bar{K}$ and UBIK is a Yes instance, which completes the proof.

# 5 Multi-level Critical Node Problem with unit weights 

In this section, we first recall the formal definition of the MCNP with unit weights, which is defined in [4] as a three-level problem, after which we proceed to demonstrate its $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$-completeness.

Multi-level Critical Node Problem The MCNP is defined on an undirected graph $G=(V, A)$. First, the defender selects a subset of vertices $D \subseteq V$ to vaccinate, subject to a vaccination budget $\Omega$ and weight $\hat{c}_{v}$ for each $v \in V$. Then, the attacker selects a subset of vertices $I \subseteq V \backslash D$ to (directly) infect, subject to an infection budget $\Phi$ and weight $h_{v}$ for $v \in V$. Finally, the defender selects a subset of vertices $P \subseteq V \backslash I$ to protect, subject to a protection budget $\Lambda$ and weight $c_{v}$ for $v \in V$. A directly or indirectly infected vertex $v$ propagates the infection to a vertex $u$, if $(v, u) \in A$ and $u$ is neither vaccinated nor protected. The goal of the defender is to maximise the benefit $b_{v}$ of saved vertices (i.e., not infected), while the attacker aims to minimise it. We assume that all parameters of the problem are non-negative integers.

The game description can be succinctly given by the following mixed integer trilevel program:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (M C N) \max _{z \in\{0,1\}^{|V|} \min _{y \in\{0,1\}^{|V|}} \max _{x \in\{0,1\}^{|V|} \sum_{v \in V} b_{v} \alpha_{v} \\
& \sum_{v \in V} \hat{c}_{v} z_{v} \leq \Omega \quad \sum_{v \in V} h_{v} y_{v} \leq \Phi \\
& \text { s.t. } \sum_{v \in V} c_{v} x_{v} \leq \Lambda \\
& \alpha_{v} \leq 1+z_{v}-y_{v}, \quad \forall v \in V \\
& \alpha_{v} \leq \alpha_{u}+x_{v}+z_{v}, \quad \forall(u, v) \in A
\end{aligned}
$$

where $z, y, x$ and $\alpha$ are binary decision vectors whose coordinates are $z_{v}, y_{v}, x_{v}$ and $\alpha_{v}$ for each $v \in V$. In this optimisation model, $z, y$ and $x$ reflect the set of vaccinated vertices $D=\left\{v \in V: z_{v}=1\right\}$, directly infected vertices $I=\left\{v \in V: y_{v}=1\right\}$ and protected vertices $P=\left\{v \in V: x_{v}=1\right\}$, respectively. Finally, $\alpha$ mimics the propagation of the infection among the vertices in $V$, through Constraints (1a) and (1b). Concretely, $\alpha_{v}=1$ means that vertex $v$ is saved and $\alpha_{v}=0$ means that vertex $v$ is infected. See [4] for further details on this mathematical programming formulation and Figure 5 for an illustration of the game.

![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Figure 5: Example of an MCN game with unitary weights and benefits, and budgets $\Omega=\Phi=\Lambda=1$. At the end of the game, vertices $\left\{v_{1}, v_{3}, v_{4}\right\}$ are saved and $\left\{v_{2}, v_{6}, v_{5}\right\}$ are infected.

We recall that this problem was proved to be $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$-complete on trees, with arbitrary integer weights, in [28]. In the following we will concentrate on the unweighted version, tackled numerically in [4], for which all the weights previously described are unitary.
$\Sigma_{3}^{p}$-completeness of the MCNP with unit weights We now demonstrate the completeness of the MCNP with unit weights for the third level of the polynomial hierarchy. This version of the MCNP is defined as:

Unitary Multi-Level Critical Node (UMCN):
INSTANCE: An undirected graph $G=(V, A)$, three positive integer maximum cardinalities $\Omega, \Phi$ and $\Lambda$ and a positive integer goal $\bar{K}$.
QUESTION: Is there a subset $D \subseteq V$ of vertices, with $|D| \leq \Omega$, such that for every subset $I \subseteq V \backslash D$, with $|I| \leq \Phi$, there is a subset $P \subseteq V \backslash I$, with $|P| \leq \Lambda$, such that the cardinality of the saved vertices is at least $\bar{K}$ ?

In order to prove the $\Sigma_{3}^{p}$-completeness of the above problem, we will use $\mathcal{B}_{3} \cap 3 C N F$ as in Section 2.
Let us introduce the following reduction from the $\mathcal{B}_{3} \cap 3 C N F$ :

- For each literal $\lambda=u$ or $\lambda=\bar{u}$ with $u \in U$, we introduce in the graph a vertex $v_{\lambda}$. We also define $V_{X}=\left\{v_{x}, v_{\bar{x}}: x \in X\right\}, V_{Y}=\left\{v_{y}, v_{\bar{y}}: y \in Y\right\}$ and $V_{Z}=\left\{v_{z}, v_{\bar{z}}: z \in Z\right\}$.
- For each unordered pair of literals $\left\{\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right\}$ with $\lambda, \lambda^{\prime} \in\{x, \bar{x}\}, \lambda \neq \lambda^{\prime}$ and $x \in X$, we add a gadget (see the left part of Figure 6), composed by a set $C_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}$ of $\Gamma_{X}$ vertices, all connected with $v_{\lambda}$ and $v_{\lambda^{\prime}}$. The cardinality $\Gamma_{X}$ is suitably defined in the following. The aim of these gadgets is to turn each couple of vertices from $V_{X}$ into a vertex cut, so that protecting both vertices allows to save $C_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}$. Since this does not hold for the couple of vertices $\left(v_{x}, v_{\bar{x}}\right)$ for each $x \in X$, it will be effective to protect only one vertex from such couples.
- For each literal $\lambda=y$ or $\lambda=\bar{y}$ with $y \in Y$, we introduce a set $S_{\lambda}$ of $\Gamma_{Y}$ vertices, each with an edge linking it to $v_{\lambda}$. Therefore, $v_{y}$ and $v_{\bar{y}}$ are at the centre of a substar inside the graph. We also introduce a set $K_{y}$ of $\Gamma_{Y}$ vertices, all linked to both $v_{y}$ and $v_{\bar{y}}$. The value of $\Gamma_{Y}$ is defined in the following. We provide a graphic illustration of such a gadget in the central part of Figure 6.
- We add edges between each vertex of $V_{X} \cup V_{Z}$ and each vertex of $V_{Y}$.
- For each unordered pair of literals $\left\{\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right\}$ with $\lambda, \lambda^{\prime} \in\{z, \bar{z}\}$ with $z \in Z, \lambda \neq \lambda^{\prime}$ and $\lambda \neq \bar{\lambda}^{\prime}$, we introduce a set $C_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}$ of $\Gamma_{Z}$ vertices, all connected with $v_{\lambda}$ and $v_{\lambda^{\prime}}$. The cardinality $\Gamma_{Z}$ is suitably defined in the following. The aim of this set of gadgets is once again to allow each couple of vertices from $V_{Z}$ to be part of a vertex cut, so that protecting both vertices allows to save $C_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}$. Since this does not hold for the couple of vertices $\left(v_{z}, v_{\bar{z}}\right)$ for each $z \in Z$, it will be effective to protect only one vertex from such couples.
- For each clause $c \in C$, let $k_{c} \leq 3$ be the number of literals included in the clause. We enumerate the $2^{k_{c}}-1$ variable assignments that satisfy the clause (excluding only the one which negates all literals) and introduce a vertex $v_{c}^{i}$ (with $i=1, \ldots, 2^{k_{c}}-1$ ) for each corresponding set of literals. We define as $V_{C}$ the set of all such vertices. These vertices are connected by edges to the corresponding vertices in $V_{X}, V_{Y}$ and $V_{Z}$.

The aim of these gadgets is to guarantee that exactly one of the vertices in each clause gadget will be saved if at least one of the vertices associated to the literals is vaccinated or protected, and no vertex is saved otherwise. We provide a graphic illustration of such a gadget in the right part of Figure 6.

- We set the vaccination budget as $\Omega=|X|$, the infection budget as $\Phi=|X|+|Y|$ and the protection budget as $\Lambda=|Y|+|Z|$. We set the profit goal at $K=\Gamma_{X}|X|(|X|-1) / 2+|X|+|Y|\left(\Gamma_{Y}+1\right)+\Gamma_{Z}|Z|(|Z|-1) / 2+$ $|Z|+|C|$. Finally, we set $\Gamma_{Z}=|C|+1, \Gamma_{Y}=\Gamma_{Z}|Z|(|Z|-1) / 2+1$ and $\Gamma_{X}=4|Y| \Gamma_{Y}+1$. This guarantees that it is more advantageous to save or infect (from the point of view of the defender or the attacker, respectively) vertices from $V_{X}$ first, from $V_{Y}$ second, and lastly from $V_{Z}$.
![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)

Figure 6: On the left part: example of a gadget between the vertices associated to two variables $x, x^{\prime} \in X$ (which forms a bi-partite graph). The black dots denote the rest of the sets elliptically. On the middle part: example of a gadget associated to a variable $y \in Y$. The black dots denote the rest of the sets elliptically. On the right part: example of a gadget associated to a clause $c=x \wedge y \wedge \neg z$ with $x \in X, y \in Y$ and $z \in Z$. The only missing configuration on the right is the one of the negation of the clause, i.e., $\neg x \wedge \neg y \wedge z$, therefore in the case this expression is true in the SAT instance, no vertex on the right is saved from infection.

The reduction is polynomial because the number of vertices and edges of the graph is polynomial in the instance size.
We proceed to prove some useful properties about the solutions to MCNP instances created above:
Property 5.1. In every Yes instance of UMCN, the defender must vaccinate either vertex $v_{x}$ or $v_{x}$ for each $x \in X$ in order to reach the profit goal.

Proof. First of all, notice that, once a vertex $v_{\lambda} \in V_{X} \cup V_{Y} \cup V_{Z}$ is infected, the only way for the defender to save the vertices from the sets $C_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}$ or $S_{\lambda}$ or the ones in $V_{C}$ that correspond to truth assignments using $\lambda$ is to vaccinate or protect them individually. This is ineffective when compared to the vaccination or protection of vertices from $V_{X}$, $V_{Y}$ and $V_{Z}$, that indirectly save also the adjacent vertices. Second, with the given $\Gamma$ parameters and in order to reach the profit goal, the defender must save at least $|X|(|X|-1) / 2$ subsets $C_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}$ of $\Gamma_{X}$ vertices by spending the whole vaccination budget on $V_{X}$. Otherwise, the attacker can infect $|X|+1$ vertices from $V_{X}$ directly, and the corresponding subsets $C_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}$ indirectly. Moreover, if the defender does not vaccinate exactly one vertex between $v_{x}$ and $v_{x}$ for each $x \in X$, then some couples are completely vaccinated while others have both vertices unvaccinated, and therefore prone to infection. By construction, since the pairs $\left(v_{x}, v_{x}\right)$ do not have a corresponding $C$ subset, the number of saved subsets $C_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}$ is strictly less than $|X|(|X|-1) / 2$ and the profit goal $K$ cannot be reached.

Property 5.2. If the defender vaccinates exactly one vertex for each pair in $V_{X}$ and the attacker does not infect exactly one vertex for each pair in $V_{Y}$, the defender can always reach the profit goal.

Proof. If the defender vaccinates exactly one vertex for each pair in $V_{X}$, the attacker must infect all unvaccinated $V_{X}$ vertices. Otherwise, the defender will save at least $\Gamma_{X}|X|(|X|+1) / 2>\bar{K}$ vertices. With the remaining $|Y|$ units of attack, infecting a vertex from the $C_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}$ set for literals $\lambda$ and $\lambda^{\prime}$ of $X$ only infects this single vertex (a similar reasoning applies to the vertices of the $S_{\lambda}$ and $K_{y}$ sets, as well as the $C_{\lambda \lambda^{\prime}}$ sets for $\lambda$ and $\lambda^{\prime}$ being $Z$-related literals). Moreover, this attack would leave a remaining budget of $|Y|-1$ vertices. From the remaining vertices of the graph, those of $V_{Y}$ are the ones with the largest number of adjacent nodes that can easily be saved by protecting a vertex in $V_{Y}$. Consequently, the defender can use $|Y|+1$ units from the protection budget to protect $|Y|+1$ vertices from $V_{Y}$ to obtain a number of saved vertices greater than $\Gamma_{X}|X|(|X|-1) / 2+|X|+\Gamma_{Y}(|Y|+2)>\bar{K}$.
Moreover, the attacker must infect either vertex $v_{y}$ or $v_{\bar{y}}$ for each $y \in Y$. Otherwise, there exists $y \in Y$ such that neither $v_{y}$ nor $v_{\bar{y}}$ are directly infected. Since the defender has enough budget to protect the $|Y|$ vertices of $V_{Y}$ not infected, both $v_{y}$ and $v_{\bar{y}}$ can be protected, saving the stars around the two vertices and the set $K_{y}$ linked to both vertices. This generates a number of saved vertices larger than $\Gamma_{X}|X|(|X|-1) / 2+|X|+\Gamma_{Y}(|Y|+2)>\bar{K}$, which completes the proof.

Property 5.3.
